newsitem.title: USA: Late NYMEX Hub natgas still mixed, range-bound.
newsitem.headline: Late NYMEX Hub natgas still mixed, range-bound.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures remained narrowly mixed late Friday in sluggish trade, with a steady to firmer physical market underpinning the complex although prices stayed stuck in recent technical ranges.
At 1410 EDT, July was 1.2 cents lower at $2.165 per million British thermal units, while August was down 0.3 cent at $2.18. Other months remained on either side of unchanged.

"Injections (storage buying) may put a floor under the market, but the weather is still bearish and I don't see it taking off to the upside," said a New York trader, noting 6-10 day forecasts were still calling for mostly seasonal temps.
Some revised forecasts now call for normal Midwest and Northeast weather through next week, with the Southwest and southern California the only areas expected above-normal.

Traders said steady injection demand, particularly with spreads now more attractive, has helped underpin both physical and paper prices, but few expected a significant rally without a broader heat wave to stir some air conditioning demand.

Traders said there was little or no effect from a small, natural gas line leak in the Vermilion Bay area offshore Louisiana. Several lines were shut last night for testing, but major pipeline operators said Friday flows were normal.

Technical traders agreed recent ranges were intact, with resistance in July still at $2.25, and then at $2.37 and the contract high of $2.44. Support was seen at $2.10, with straonger buying expected at $2.08.

In the weekend cash, Gulf Coast prices firmed slightly Friday to the mid-teens. Midcon pipes were two to three cents higher at about $2.05. New York city gate gas prices were up slightly to about $2.40.
NYMEX said 14,145 contracts traded by 1340 EDT. Hub open interest on June 5 fell 1,375 lots to 195,368.
On KCBT, July slipped 1.5 cents to $2.035, while deferreds were mixed. The East/West spread widened by 0.3 cents to 13.0 cents (NYMEX premium).
